qas.question: The Luftwaffe used how many short tons of bombs during the Blitz?
The Luftwaffe helped the U-boats by sinking how much shipping?
How did the British production fare as a result of all the bombing?

answers.text: overall the British production rose steadily throughout this period

qas.question: What was the greatest achievement of the bombings?

answers.text: British were denied the opportunity to reach the planned target of 2,500 aircraft in a month

qas.question: How long was the recovery of industrial cities from raids?

context: The military effectiveness of bombing varied. The Luftwaffe dropped around <a0_0>45,000 short tons<a0_0/> (41,000 t) of bombs during the Blitz disrupting production and transport, reducing food supplies and shaking the British morale. It also helped to support the U-Boat blockade by sinking some <a1_0>58,000 long tons<a1_0/> (59,000 t) of shipping destroyed and 450,000 long tons (460,000 t) damaged. Yet, <a2_0>overall the British production rose steadily throughout this period<a2_0/> although there were significant falls during April 1941, probably influenced by the departure of workers of Easter Holidays according to the British official history. The British official history on war production noted the great impact was upon the supply of components rather than complete equipment. In aircraft production, the <a3_0>British were denied the opportunity to reach the planned target of 2,500 aircraft in a month<a3_0/>, arguably the greatest achievement of the bombing, as it forced the dispersal of industry. In April 1941, when the targets were British ports, rifle production fell by 25%, filled-shell production by 4.6%, and in smallarms production 4.5% overall. The strategic impact on industrial cities was varied; <a4_0>most took from 10–15 days<a4_0/> to recover from heavy raids, although Belfast and Liverpool took longer. The attacks against Birmingham took war industries some three months to recover fully from. The exhausted population took three weeks to overcome the effects of an attack.
